texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My daily workflow includes taking tons of screenshots. I'm constantly relaying views of different data or results of various work between different chat systems and emails. As with all things that I do often, I look for ways to optimize them as much as possible.
texts.text: My daily workflow includes taking tons of screenshots. I'm constantly relaying views of different data or results of various work between different chat systems and emails. As with all things that I do often, I look for ways to optimize them as much as possible.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: (I'm that guy who wrote a post on an  efficient emoji workflow in Wayland .)  😂
texts.text: (I'm that guy who wrote a post on an  efficient emoji workflow in Wayland .)  😂

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Screenshots must be easy to take and share, period. Modern versions of Firefox make this extremely easy with the built-in screenshot mechanism.
texts.text: Screenshots must be easy to take and share, period. Modern versions of Firefox make this extremely easy with the built-in screenshot mechanism.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Right click an element on a web page, choose  Take Screenshot  from the pop-up and screenshot a whole page or just a single DOM element. From there, you can copy it directly to the clipboard and paste it elsewhere or save it to a file.
texts.text: Right click an element on a web page, choose  Take Screenshot  from the pop-up and screenshot a whole page or just a single DOM element. From there, you can copy it directly to the clipboard and paste it elsewhere or save it to a file.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I want something as close to that for the i3 desktop environment.
texts.text: I want something as close to that for the i3 desktop environment.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Fortunately, there's a piece of software called  maim ![^maimname] The README in the repository contains lots of helpful examples for basic screenshots all the way up to fancy conversions with drop shadows. ✨
texts.text: Fortunately, there's a piece of software called  maim ![^maimname] The README in the repository contains lots of helpful examples for basic screenshots all the way up to fancy conversions with drop shadows. ✨

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My use case is quite simple. I want to press a key, get a selection crosshair, make my selection, and get my screenshot copied to the clipboard.
texts.text: My use case is quite simple. I want to press a key, get a selection crosshair, make my selection, and get my screenshot copied to the clipboard.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Here's how I do it in i3:
texts.text: Here's how I do it in i3:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: bindsym Print exec maim -s -u | xclip -selection clipboard -t image/png -i
texts.text: bindsym Print exec maim -s -u | xclip -selection clipboard -t image/png -i

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Once the selection is made, the image pipes straight into
texts.text: Once the selection is made, the image pipes straight into

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I'm able to go to my favorite application or browser window with Slack, Discord, or Mastodon open and simply paste the image into my message. 🏁
texts.text: I'm able to go to my favorite application or browser window with Slack, Discord, or Mastodon open and simply paste the image into my message. 🏁

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: [^maimname]: Before you get upset with the name, keep in mind that it's the shortened version of  make image . 😉
texts.text: [^maimname]: Before you get upset with the name, keep in mind that it's the shortened version of  make image . 😉
